awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  India at the Crossroads--Biotic Change in Continental Vertebrates Across the Cretaceous-Paleogene
awd_abstract_narration:
The end of the Cretaceous Period (66 million years ago) is marked by a mass extinction event that led to the demise of many organisms on land and sea, including non-avian dinosaurs, and fostered the diversification of others, such as modern mammals. At the time of this event, the Indian Subcontinent was in the midst of geographic and geological upheaval. As it migrated northward across the equator, it passed over a volcanic hot spot that breached the crust and led to massive outpouring of basalt lava onto the continent forming the Deccan Traps. The effects of these events on India's land biota remain poorly understood due to understudy of India's geological and paleontological record during this time. The goals of this project are to improve understanding of (1) the timing and nature of Deccan volcanism and (2) its biological effects in continental organisms. Improved understanding of the biotic response to major geographic and geologic changes in India will allow comparisons with the record in North America and will inform studies of the interchange of organisms that resulted from India's subsequent collision with Asia.

This project brings together expertise in paleontology and Deccan Trap volcanology, geophysics, geochronology, sedimentology and stratigraphy of Trap-associated deposits. Traditional geological and paleontological techniques will be employed, as well as state-of-the-art radioisotopic dating, chemical fingerprinting, and study of magnetism preserved in basalts that are associated with key fossil beds. Research conducted as part of this project will be incorporated into Immersive Virtual Field Trips (iVFTs), which are cyber-learning applications that allow teachers to virtually take students to scientifically significant but inaccessible environments. iVFTs use location-based high-resolution spherical content, 360° panoramic video, giga-pixel imagery, and unique viewpoints via unmanned aerial vehicles (drones) to develop interactive, content-rich, and learner-driven virtual field explorations, experienced online via HTML5.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project centered on dating lavas using the 40Ar/39Ar method applied to lavas in the Deccan Traps Large Igneous Province, to constrain the ages of vertebrate animal fossils occuring above, below, and in between the lavas. The fossil assemblages of interest span the time before, during and after one of Earth's most severe mass extinctions 66 million years ago, when the non-avian dinosaurs and numerous other animals went extinct. Results showed that placental mammals had evolved in India, as in North America, by latest Cretaceous time, prior to the mass extinction. Other fossil assemblages in the region can now be viewed in the context of their temporal relationships to the mass extinction, including the dynamics of how the food web recovered after the extinction. A statistical study revealed that the coincidence between Large Igneous Provinces and mass extinctions in general is extremely unlikely to have occurred by chance. Combining geochemistry of lavas with our dating results showed that geochemical trends in the evolution of lavas did not occur synchronously throughout the Deccan Province, hence these trends cannot be used as a proxy for time except at very local spatial scales. Fundamental changes in the chemistry and erupive style and tempo of the lavas are now shown to coincide with global climatic changes, including the cooling event that immediately preceded the mass extinction.

Broader Impacts

This project produced numerous results of interest to the geophysical community regarding the geodynamic evolution of the Deccan Traps Large Igneous Province. A southward propagating onset of volcanism is now well established, supporting the hypothesis that the Deccan Traps magmas were produced by the motion of the Indian tectonic plate over a mantle plume (hot spot). Geochemical trends over time indicate that the lavas were erupted from multiple magma chambers rather than a single central source. Massive, buoyant crystal mushes were erupted episodically throughout the province, likely driven by CO2 exsolution, implying a regionak forcing mechanism such as tectonic earthquakes originating in the Himalayan subduction zone. Three PhD students (two female) were supported by this grant, and received training in field methods, geochronology, geochemistry and paleomagnetism. Two of these students now hold faculty positions at major research universities and the third is finishing. The PI initiated ongoing collaborations with Indian colleagues.
